news_header: BHP and Vale agree to pay $23 billion in damages for a 2015 dam collapse in Brazil that caused significant environmental damage and loss of life.
news_text: Mining companies BHP and Vale signed a deal with the Brazilian government to pay nearly 132 billion reais ($23 billion) for damages resulting from a 2015 dam collapse in Mariana, Brazil, which killed 19 people and caused extensive environmental destruction. The agreement includes 100 billion reais in new resources to be paid over 20 years, with the first installment of 5 billion due within 30 days. The remaining 32 billion will be used for compensation and resettlement of around 300,000 affected individuals. This payout follows previous agreements and ongoing lawsuits, with over 620,000 complainants seeking additional damages. Brazilian President Lula highlighted the deal as the largest environmental payout in modern history, emphasizing the need for mining firms to prioritize safety over profit.
